review.title: Acquisition of Translation Lexicons for Historically Unwritten Languages via Bridging Loanwords
review.abstract: With the advent of informal electronic communications such as social media, colloquial languages that were historically unwritten are being written for the first time in heavily code-switched environments. We present a method for inducing portions of translation lexicons through the use of expert knowledge in these settings where there are approximately zero resources available other than a language informant, potentially not even large amounts of monolingual data. We investigate inducing a Moroccan Darija-English translation lexicon via French loanwords bridging into English and find that a useful lexicon is induced for human-assisted translation and statistical machine translation.

metadata.title: Acquisition of Translation Lexicons for Historically Unwritten Languages via Bridging Loanwords

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: With the explosive growth of informal electronic communications such as e-mail, social media, web commentary, and so on, slang languages that have historically been unwritten are beginning to be written for the first time. Extremely limited (about zero) resources are available for these languages, not even large amounts of monolingual text data or possibly even small amounts of monolingual text data. Even when audio resources are available, difficulties arise in converting sound to text (Tratz et al., 2013; Robinson and Gadelii, 2003). In addition, the text data that can be obtained often have non-standard spellings and substantial code exchanges with other traditionally written languages (Tratz et al., 2013). In this paper, we present a method for acquiring translation lexicons via loanwords and expertise that requires zero resources for borrowing language.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments and Discussion
sections.text: In our experiments, we extracted a French bilingual dictionary using the freely available English Wiktion platform 20131101 downloaded from http: / / dumps.wikimedia. org / enwiktionary. From this dump, we extracted all the French words, their pronunciation and their English definitions. Using the process described in Section 3 to convert each of the French pronunciations into a Moroccan script, we produced 8277 unique loanword candidate strings. The data used for testing consists of one million lines of user comments provided by the Moroccan news website http: / / www.hespress.com. The crawled user comments contain marokkarija in strongly coded environments. While this is a challenging setting, it is a realistic representation of the types of environments in which historically unwritten languages are written for the first time.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: With the explosive growth of informal textual electronic communication such as social media, web commentary, etc., many everyday colloquial languages that were historically unwritten are now often written in heavily coded text with traditionally written languages for the first time. However, the new written versions of these languages present significant challenges to multilingual processing technology due to OOV challenges. Nevertheless, it is relatively common for these historically unwritten languages to borrow significant amounts of vocabulary from relatively well-equipped written languages. We presented a method of loanword induction to alleviate the OOV challenges in these environments, where the borrowed language has extremely limited resources, in many cases not even significant amounts of monolingual data commonly used by previous cognates and loan word recognition methods to induce translation lexicons. This paper shows that the introduction of a Martian Dokaric-English translation system can increase the performance of the lexical French translation system over the lexical language.
